metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: TOGETHER is not a true character but rather a capitalized imperative word embedded in Cassandra's dialogue, used for dramatic emphasis. It appears as part of the stage direction formatting convention where key words are capitalized mid-speech to underscore their weight. In context, Cassandra commands Dante to 'pull it TOGETHER,' making TOGETHER a stylistic device rather than a person, entity, or role.
data.dialogue_summary: TOGETHER has no dialogue of its own. It appears solely as a capitalized word within Cassandra's speech directed at Dante, functioning as a rhetorical and typographical emphasis on the command to compose herself.

explicit_evidence.quote: I need you to cut this scared little girl shit and pull it TOGETHER.

inferred_traits.rationale: TOGETHER appears only once in the script as a capitalized word within Cassandra's dialogue, consistent with the screenplay's convention of capitalizing significant words for dramatic effect (e.g., BOOTHS, DEFICIENCIES IN THAT DEPARTMENT). It has no independent dialogue, actions, or presence.
inferred_traits.value: Typographical/stylistic emphasis rather than a speaking character

data.name: TOGETHER
